docs.lead_paragraph: Whether he is writing books, lecturing at universities or lobbying regulators and politicians, Jeremy Rifkin never misses a chance to argue that the biotechnology industry is leading the world toward environmental and social disaster. If he thinks it will help slow the industry down, he is quick to file lawsuits and promote boycotts or moratoriums. But last week, the activist who was once described by critics as the ''abominable no-man'' took on another role. Intrigued by an invitation to an industry meeting at one of biotechnology's inner sanctums, he happily trekked to the headquarters of the Monsanto Company here to offer up his vision of the future. ''I've never been to a meeting like this in the 23 years I've been talking about these issues,'' he said.

headline.main: Plotting Corporate Futures; Biotechnology Examines What Could Go Wrong

docs.abstract: Biotechnology industry has developed insect-resistant crops and blockbuster drugs, but critics are raising concerns about threats to health and environment, prompting industry to think hard about where it is headed; industry critic Jeremy Rifkin was called into meeting last week by Ulrich Goluke, consultant hired by Monsanto Co and 13 members of World Business Council for Sustainable Development, to help them predict what biotechnology industry will be like in year 2030; exercise, known as story building, or more formally as scenario creation, is specialized form of crystal-ball gazing that big corporations are increasingly turning to as early warning system for how their strategies could go astray; scenario creation was originally developed for Federal Government in 1950's at Rand Corp to study how nuclear wars might start; biotechnology companies see plenty of reason to worry about unpredictable setbacks; while genetically engineered crops like soybeans and corn and number of drugs have been commerical hits, critics are stepping up their efforts to portray advances as fraught with threats to human health and environment; drawing; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Whether he is writing books, lecturing at universities or lobbying regulators and politicians, Jeremy Rifkin never misses a chance to argue that the biotechnology industry is leading the world toward environmental and social disaster. If he thinks it...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court today set aside a $1.5 billion landmark settlement that was to have resolved the claims of as many as 186,000 victims of asbestos poisoning against the Fibreboard Corporation, one of the leading makers of products using the fire-retardant substance. The Justices concluded that the lawyers for the claimants had a possible conflict of interest: getting the most for their clients and striking a quick deal that would garner huge legal fees. They also found that in approving an agreement that would have sharply limited any other lawsuits brought against Fibreboard, the lower court had failed to consider that there was almost certainly more money available for the claims, because Fibreboard was only contributing $500,000, with its insurers putting up the rest. Fibreboard was sold to Owens Corning two years ago for $515 million.

headline.main: Justices Throw Out $1.5 Billion Asbestos Settlement, Citing Possible Conflict of Interest

docs.abstract: Supreme Court, in 7 to 2 ruling, sets aside $1.5 billion landmark settlement that was to have resolved claims of as many as 186,000 victims of asbestos poisoning against Fibreboard Corp; concludes that lawyers for claimants had possible conflict of interest: getting most for their clients and striking quick deal that would garner huge legal fees; Justice David H Souter writes majority opinion; Justice Stephen G Breyer and Justice John Paul Stevens write dissenting opinion (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE White House conference earlier this month on mental illness highlighted the Administration's campaign, led by Tipper Gore, to achieve ''parity for all'' -- requiring health insurers to provide the same coverage for mental illness that they provide for physical illness. Bills in Congress would do the same. The call for parity raises two questions. Is coverage of mental health the same as that of physical health? And who should decide?

headline.main: Economic Scene; Solutions can become problems for mental illness insurance.

docs.abstract: Economic Scene column on providing health insurance for mental illness; says new study by Richard G Frank of Harvard University and Thomas G McGuire of Boston University shows that powerful economic forces compel plans to discriminate between physical and mental health; holds Congress may still want to proceed on bill to provide coverage, but markets will counteract parity in ways that advocates will almost surely not like; says Frank-McGuire study offers economic reasons why employers do not offer parity with insurance for physical illnesses; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Declaring that a majority of the Supreme Court fundamentally misunderstood the purpose of the Americans with Disabilities Act, advocates for the disabled began to scramble today for legal and political strategies to counter a Court ruling this week that limited the law's protections. Senator Tom Harkin, the Iowa Democrat who was one of the chief sponsors of the 1990 legislation, raised the possibility of seeking ''some kind of legislative remedy'' to override the Court's ruling on Tuesday, when it took a restrictive view of the definition of disability under the law. But the Senator added: ''It's unclear where we go from here. I think this will send a shock wave through the disability community.''

headline.main: Ruling Upsets Advocates for the Disabled

docs.abstract: Advocates for disabled say that majority of Supreme Court fundamentally misunderstands purpose of Americans with Disabilities Act; are seeking legal and political strategies to counter Court ruling that limits law's protections; Sen Tom Harkin, one of chief sponsors of 1990 legislation, raises possibility of seeking 'legislative remedy' to override Court's ruling (M)

byline.original: By ROBIN TONER and LESLIE KAUFMAN

docs.lead_paragraph: The American Medical Association, which long considered itself an elite professional organization, voted yesterday to form a union for doctors in what it called an effort to level the playing field with powerful managed-care organizations. At a delegates annual meeting in Chicago, the 290,000-member association decided to jettison its anti-unionization stance because so many doctors complain of feeling powerless in their dealings with health maintenance organizations.
docs.abstract: American Medical Association, at its annual meeting in Chicago, votes to form union for doctors in what it calls effort to level playing field with powerful managed-care organizations; votes to set up branch that will work to unionize two groups of doctors--those who are salaried employees and medical residents--which together represent about one-third of nation's 620,000 practicing physicians; health industry experts say AMA's decision underlines how sweeping changes have been in health-care industry and how frustrated and angry thousands of doctors have become; association, which represents 34 percent of nation's doctors, felt pressure to act because several of nation's most powerful unions were already seeking to unionize doctors; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate was paralyzed for a third straight day today as Democrats pressed for immediate consideration of legislation to define patients' rights within their health insurance plans. Republicans rejected the Democrats' timetable and terms, and leaders from both parties sought in vain to devise a way around the impasse. Democrats continued to block action on an agriculture spending bill -- and threatened to similarly impede any other legislation -- until they got a solid promise of a full-fledged debate, within the next few weeks, on new regulations for health maintenance organizations and medical insurers.

headline.main: Democrats Stall Senate to Force Debate on Health Care

docs.abstract: Senate is paralyzed for third consecutive day as Democrats press for immediate consideration of legislation to define patients' rights within their health insurance plans, blocking action on agriculture spending bill and threatening to impede other legislation; Republicans reject Democrat's timetable and terms, as leaders of both parties seek in vain to devise way around impasse; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The annual grants popularly known as the genius awards announced yesterday by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation were heavily weighted toward the New York area, home to about a third of the 32 recipients. ''There is a clump there this year because we just couldn't pass them up,'' said Daniel J. Socolow, director of the MacArthur Fellows program.
docs.abstract: John D and Catherine T MacArthur Foundation awards 32 fellowships, popularly known as genius awards; awards, ranging from $235,000 to $375,000 each over five years, are aimed at enabling recipients to pursue any interests they desire; list (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Evidence of Mass Graves Is Mounting in Kosovo Serbian forces dug up the bodies of about 100 Kosovo Albanians from a mass grave Djakovica late last month and carried them off, the municipal official in charge of burials said. The disclosure came as investigators, journalists and human rights workers were finding growing evidence of graves and widespread destruction throughout Kosovo. A12 NATO's senior commander, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, said the allies should speed up the deployment of their troops to Kosovo, and he suggested that more than 50,000 peacekeepers might be needed. A12

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders pulled back today from their threat to make the state's health care industry a casualty of the fight over the state budget. Mr. Pataki and the leaders agreed to continue making Medicaid payments to hospitals and other health care providers while the negotiations over the budget, now 83 days late, dragged on.

headline.main: Pataki Avoids A Showdown On Payments For Medicaid

docs.abstract: New York Gov George E Pataki and legislative leaders agree to continue making Medicaid payments to hospitals and other health care providers while budget negotiations drag on (M)
